description: From Middle English preceptor, preceptur, from Latin praeceptor (“commander; instructor”), from the verb praecipiō + -or (“-er: forming agent nouns”), from prae- (“pre-, fore-: before”) + capiō (“to take; to get, to take in, to understand”).

examples: A man who had thought so much on the subjects of language and education was surely no ordinary preceptor.

entries.meaning: (historical) The head of a preceptory of Knights Templar. [from 15th c.]
(medicine, chiefly US) A doctor who gives practical training to medical students, nurses etc. [from 19th c.]
